newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: CRICKET-PAKISTAN TIGHTEN GRIP IN SECOND TEST.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-PAKISTAN TIGHTEN GRIP IN SECOND TEST.

text.p: Fast bowlers Wasim Akram and Waqar Younis made early inroads into Zimbabwe's second innings after Pakistan took a 134-run first innings lead in the second and deciding test on Friday.

Akram trapped Grant Flower lbw with his second delivery and Younis claimed Mark Dekker's wicket in a similar fashion with his first ball to leave the touring side nine for two at tea on the second day.
Pakistan were earlier all out for 267 in their first innings in reply to Zimbabwe's 133.
The home side added 32 to their lunch score of 235 for seven before losing their last wicket 40 minutes before tea.
Starting the day at 114 for three, Pakistan lost Saeed Anwar (81), Hasan Raza (27), Wasim Akram (35) and Mohammad Hussain (0) in the morning session.
Anwar, 69 overnight, smashed three more boundaries before he chased a wide delivery from paceman Everton Matambanadzo and edged an easy catch to Andy Flower behind the stumps.

His partner Raza, the youngest player to appear in a test match at the age of 14 years and 227 days, added seven runs to his overnight 20 before he edged a catch to David Houghton at first slip off leg-spinner Paul Strang.
Moin Khan failed to add to his lunchtime score of 58 but Waqar Younis hit 23 with five fours to put his side into a strong position.
Left-arm seamer Bryan Strang finished with three for 53.
At the tea interval David Houghton was on nine and Craig Wishart on nought.
